block.p: 300 U.N. Peacekeepers Are Held in Sierra Leone Rebels now hold more than 300 United Nations troops hostage, and contact has been lost with some peacekeeping units, officials said.

War and Censorship in Sri Lanka The government said troops had pushed back Tamil rebels trying to capture the northern city of Jaffna. Officials also deleted portions of news agency reports describing an opposition rally to protest the authorities' broad new powers.

New Effort on Ulster The British and Irish governments said they had agreed on a formula to restart the suspended power-sharing government in Belfast and they urged Ulster's Catholic and Protestant leaders to endorse it.

Swiss Banks Holocaust Offer Representatives of Swiss commercial banks and Holocaust survivors are expected to present final details of a $1.25 billion restitution settlement to a federal judge next week, after two of the largest banks agreed to give the survivors' lawyers access to databases containing information on 2.1 million Nazi-era accounts, the lead lawyer for the survivors said.

Turkey Names President Parliament elected the country's top judicial official, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, to the presidency. Although it is a largely symbolic post, Mr. Sezer will be expected to help guide Turkey toward democratic changes that are crucial to Turkey's gaining entry to the European Union.

Israel Halts Lebanon Reprisals The government, which needs international support in its coming troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon, decided to discontinue reprisal bombings in Lebanon even as more guerrilla attacks took place.
Iran Holds Runoff Election Iranians voted in runoff elections for Parliament in an atmosphere of heightened suspense after the conservative crackdown on the politically ascendant reform movement.

Clinton Meets Japan Leader President Clinton and Japan's new prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, met in Washington. It was their first meeting since Mr. Mori stepped into the top job after Keizo Obuchi fell into a stroke-induced coma.

Government Investigating Ex-Director of C.I.A. The Justice Department, in a reversal of an earlier decision, has begun a criminal investigation with the F.B.I. to determine whether John M. Deutch mishandled classified material by placing it on unsecure computers in his home, officials said.

Spy Inquiry Finds Nothing Federal officials conducted a highly classified espionage investigation into whether Israeli intelligence agents had used a software company in Missouri, Amdocs, to intercept telephone conversations from the White House, State Department and other agencies, officials said. The inquiry found no evidence that that had occurred, officials said.

Pretrial Ruling in Tripp Case A Maryland judge ruled that the prosecution of Linda R. Tripp on wiretapping charges could proceed, but the judge also disallowed important testimony concerning Monica S. Lewinsky's assertions about the date of a specific conversation that Ms. Tripp secretly tape-recorded. The trial is scheduled for July 10.

Differing on Gun Lawsuits Vice President Al Gore vowed to veto any measure prohibiting cities from suing gun manufacturers, while Gov. George W. Bush suggested he might support such a measure. Mr. Bush also cast the vice president as a candidate whose advocacy of more stringent restrictions on firearms was simply the latest fashion, not a matter of steadfast principle.

Gore's Proposals on Teachers Vice President Al Gore promised to spend billions to recruit new teachers and increase teachers' salaries, but only if the states and teachers' unions agreed that all new teachers meet rigorous national standards and only if hiring decisions are based on expertise, not seniority alone.

Mississippi Flag Commission Gov. Ronnie Musgrove formed an advisory commission to design a state flag, following a court ruling that the state actually had no official flag. The flag that the state now flies has been challenged by blacks and others who resent its incorporation of a Confederate symbol.

Solemn Procession Returns The Cardinal to His Church Cardinal John O'Connor's body was brought to St. Patrick's Cathedral, beginning a period of mourning and ritual that will culminate on Monday with a funeral Mass. Burial will be in a crypt in the cathedral.

Needle Bill Is Approved The Legislature passed a measure submitted by Governor Pataki to permit the sale and possession of hypodermic needles without a prescription, an effort to slow the spread of H.I.V. among drug addicts.
No Promises in Cable Dispute Time Warner and ABC executives told the City Council that they could not guarantee that ABC programs would not be disrupted again.

Districts and Autism The needs of parents with autistic children are increasingly clashing with the bottom lines of school districts, which must pay for expensive services for students who may never set foot in district classrooms.

Chancellor Hopeful Barred Irving S. Hamer Jr., the Manhattan member of the New York City Board of Education, was barred by his colleagues from pursuing the chancellorship. Dr. Hamer responded that he would continue to withhold his support from Harold O. Levy, the interim chancellor, effectively paralyzing Mr. Levy's candidacy.
First Jewel in Triple Crown The 126th Kentucky Derby will be run today, with Fusaichi Pegasus the favorite among the field of 19.
Utah and Los Angeles Advance The Jazz beat the Seattle SuperSonics, 96-93, and the Lakers beat the Sacramento Kings, 113-86, to win their first-round N.B.A. playoff series.
3.9 Percent Jobless Rate The unemployment rate in April fell below 4 percent for the first time in 30 years, helped in part by the hiring of 73,000 more census takers.
The Dow jumped 165.37 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,577.86; the Nasdaq climbed 96.58, or 2.6 percent, to 3,816.82; and the S.& P. 500 rose 23.06, or 1.6 percent, to 1,432.63.

'I Love You' Investigation Investigators focused on the Philippines in the search for the author of the malicious program that convulsed computer networks this week. At least eight variations of the program have cropped up.

Advertising Merger Talks WPP Group of Britain said merger talks with Young & Rubicam had resumed, a week after breaking off. At the same time, Young & Rubicam continues to be courted by Publicis, the French advertising company.

Cisco Buying Switch Maker Cisco, the network equipment maker, said it would acquire ArrowPoint Communications for $5.7 billion. ArrowPoint makes specialized computers that optimize the delivery of content over the Internet.
